reviewText: Well folks, here it is. Just as the movies themselves caused quite a bit of controversy back in their day, this box-set has been subject to much criticism by rabid fans. The fact that Paramount, the company that put out these films, doesn't include every single extra possible may be a handicap to some, but to me, the novelty of owning the original "Friday The 13th" series is enough to keep me satisfied. Of course, the most recent outings -- "Jason Goes To Hell," "Jason X" and "Freddy Vs. Jason" are excluded for the obvious reason that New Line Cinema owns these flicks, thus they will never be packaged together (So you can stop holding your breath). Since Paramount was gracious enough to give these films any extras at all (the original single discs were bare-bones at best) is worth buying this set. For once, we get interviews, commentary and deleted scenes with some of the cut-out gore that we have all been craving for so long."Friday The 13th" - The series kicks off with the 1980 original "Friday The 13th," a monumental slasher flick which helped popularize the genre and served as inspiration for just about every horror movie you saw in the 80's (although, you could say "Halloween" is the father of all of that). It has great special effects by the great Tom Savini coupled with creative and often disturbing death scenes (for the time). It's hard to go camping now with this movie in mind. And oddly enough, the original movie doesn't feature Jason as the killer! Directed by: Sean S. Cunningham. 5/5"Friday The 13th, Part 2" - This sequel followed on the heels of the original's success very quickly. A return to Camp Crystal Lake, where the original took place, Jason rises from his watery grave to avenge his mother's death, and he ends up taking his frustrations out on a group of nearby camp counselors. To me, this movie is just as good as the original. Some say "re-tread" but to me, it's almost like a remake of the original with Jason in place of his mother. Some good, tense moments and a few scenes that seem almost Hitchcock-ian. Directed by: Steve Miner. 5/5"Friday The 13th, Part 3: 3D" - As far as I'm concerned, this is one os the laziest moments in the series. It's a fun little romp, even if it is crippled by the awkward 3D shots that just don't work here (how about some 3D glasses like the "Nightmare On Elm Street" set has?), but has an overall feeling of "been there, done that." However, it has some great characters, and it is the installment where Jason finds love with a hockey mask. It's also supported by some genuinely creepy moments, especially the last 5 minutes. Supported by audio-commentary from cast-members Larry Zerner (funny guy), Dana Kimmell, Paul Kratka, and Richard Brooker. Directed by: Steve Miner. 3/5"Friday The 13th, Part 4: The Final Chapter" - We all know by now that this is hardly the final chapter. And oh boy, where do I begin with this installment? I love every minute of it! It's definitely right up there as one of the best. From the shocking gore effects brought to us once again by Tom Savini, to the over-all sense of dread, to the cornball dancing of Crispin Glover (Jimbo & Ted definitely warrant their own movie), everything about this movie is complete fun. Plus, it marks the debut of Corey Feldman, who plays Tommy Jarvis, someone who we will be following and rooting for in the next few sequels. Directed by: Joseph Zito. 5/5"Friday The 13th, Part 5: A New Beginning" - This movie carries the same stigma as "Halloween 3: Season Of The Witch" does among fans, because it doesn't feature Jason as the killer! This time around, poor Tommy Jarvis, well into his teens and confined to a halfway house, finds himself being haunted by a copycat killer and the memory of Jason. Not the best in the series, but you have to give the respect to the makers of this film for trying something new. Plus, it has plenty of nudity and fun death scenes. Any sins are forgiven. Directed by: Danny Steinmann. 3/5"Friday The 13th, Part 6: Jason Lives" - Definitely a fan, and a personal, favorite. This installment boldly reinstates Jason as Camp Crystal Lakes resident slasher. Resurrected by lightning, thanks in part to Tommy Jarvis (this time around, played by genre favorite Tom Mathews), Jason gets into the old habit of offing camp-counselors in grizly fashion. This installment attempts to inject some more subtle humor into the fold and it works, surprisingly, without any nudity (which is a staple of these films)! Supported by audio-commentary from director Tom McLoughlin. 5/5"Friday The 13th, Part 7: The New Blood" - Another fan favorite, this one features Kane Hodder as Jason (who would go on to play the role in the following flick, plus "Jason Goes To Hell" and "Jason X") and special effects wizard John Carl Buechler as director. Although the film suffered more censoring possibly than any other installment in the series, it's still one hell of a rollercoaster ride. The characters are great, you love them, you hate them, you really enjoy watching some of these people getting what's theirs, courtesy of Jason. Lots of fun, and Jason looks the best he has in any other movie. Supported by audio-commentary from Hodder and Buechler. 5/5"Friday The 13th, Part 8: Jason Takes Manhattan" - The last round for Paramount has Jason riding a cruise ship full of Camp Crystal Lake graduates to New York City. As you can imagine, most of the movie takes place on the ship, with about a third taking place in Manhattan. Even so, it's a nice change of pace for the series and director Rob Hedden attempts to inject some new elements into the series. Not the best by any stretch, but a strong one nevertheless. Supported by audio-commentary from director Rob Hedden. 4/5The set is five discs, two movies featured on each, with a bonus disc dedicated to special material. This in itself is a nice feature: by confining the movies into two movies per disc, the set ends up being mucho-cheapo (moneywise, folks). "The Friday The 13th Chronicles" consists of little documentaries on the making of each film, that range anywhere between five to twenty minutes long apiece. Some of these featurettes are very informative, but when people fail to show up (case in point: Part 5 is very brief and just has Corey Feldman waxing about his own "Halloween H20"-esque "Friday" installment brainstorm. Don't call it a comeback) the results are rather dim. "Secrets Galore Behind The Gore," however, is very expansive, while "Crystal Lake Victims Tell All" is a bit brief and consists of castmembers telling little stories about how they got their part or about the making of the movies. Finally, a featurette on memorabilia collected by both fans and film-makers alike and a string of trailers round out this set. Overall, I can't really complain. I love all of these movies, and although they are still in their theatrical forms (meaning, no unrated/uncut stuff), I still, and always will, have a place in my heart for Jason and his many victims. And when you consider the shaft Paramount has given us fans in the past, one phrase comes to mind when thinking about this box-set and what is and what is not included: Good enough.
summary: Everyone's Favorite Unhappy Camper, Caught In His Prime

reviewText: I read a lot of reviews for the friday the 13th movies individually and then a bunch for the box set. I just want to say one thing...quit reading so much into these movies. These movies weren't made in hopes of an academy award. These movies were made to make you jump, scream, and go to sleep with your lights on. As the series went on, the film makers even started to make fun of the movies themselves. They are made to scare you, and keep you entertained for 90 minutes, and given that information, they did an amazing job. As an example of how people take these to seriously, I read a review recently about how in the ninth movie "jason goes to hell" it got to unrealistic when they found out jason was a worm and he could enter and take over other peoples bodies. I don't know if this person had seen the other ones but if they remember correctly, the movies are about a guy who has been shot, stabbed in the throat, set on fire, hung from a barn, buried, and electricuted, yet he keeps coming back. It isn't made to be realistic. Its made to be crazy with out of this world ideas. So, please do me and everyone else a favor. Don't take these movies so seriously, take em for what they are. Movies that are fun, scary, and entertaining. Now, onto the box set. I recently picked up the box set for $55. Think about that...it averages out to $6.88 per movie along with a complete bonus disc with hours of special features. You can't beat that. The bonus features are great. They range from how each movie was made, interviews with the actors, and how they achieved the gory affects. So in conclusion, if you are looking for a movie with sub plots, deep character developments, a good message, symbolism, and an academy award...go see Forrest Gump. However, if your looking for a movie that will keep you entertained and on the edge of your seat, with lots of scares, blood, screams, and gore...pick this box set up.

reviewText: Nobody can mistake the Friday The 13th films as being something grand in the motion picture industry. They are on a lower rung of the ladder, but they serve a purpose. They entertain those who are interested in that kind of entertainment, and basically let people just have a kind of release. I grew up on these movies. Not just these alone, but '80's horror, and the Friday films were big in the category. These films definitley make me recall a great childhood and the fun these movies brought simply because they were what they were and it was always fun to be scared. It still is today, but it gets harder to be scared when you are an adult. This boxed set was a long time coming, and for me, a simple fan who just enjoyed the ridiculousness of it all, I couldn't ask for more. I am not aware of what else is out there, and what other fans are complaining about. This gets the job done. You get the first 8 movies. From the original in 1980, to "Jason Takes Manhattan" in 1989. It will never be a complete collection since 1993's "Jason Goes To Hell", and 2002's "Jason X", were from New Line. What you get is a 5 disc collection and a load of special features. "Tales From The Cutting Room Floor" is what it sounds like. Deleted scenes and gory stuff that was trimmed or taken out entirely by the ratings board. "The Friday The 13th Chronicles" is a feature that delves into the history of the franchise and the making of each film. Cool!. "Secrets Galore Behind The Gore" looks at the workings of the FX. Most notably here are Tom Savini's work for the original and for "The Final Chapter", and John Buechler for "The New Blood". "Crystal Lake Victims Tell All" has anecdotes and musings from various cast and crew members of the series. "Friday Artifacts And Collectibles" is pretty self explanatory. Part 3 has commentray by actors Dana Kimmell, Paul Kratka, Larry Zerner, and Richard Brooker. Director Tom McLoughlin on "Jason Lives", John Buechler and Kane Hodder on "The New Blood", and director Rob Hedden on "Jason Takes Manhattan". As ridiculous as it is, there are no commentaries for the original film. Adrienne King, Betsy Palmer, and Sean Cunningham are present for other features here, so why not a commentary?. They did these things, but couldn't do commentary for the first film?. That's quite strange and infuriating as well. Where was Steve Miner?. The only director to direct two installments(2 and 3)?. It would of been nice to see Kimberly Beck, the heroine from Part 4, and Melanie Kinnaman, the heroine from Part 5. Even perennial oddball Crispin Glover, who was in Part 4, would of been interesting to see. It's also a shame that because Paramount didn't do 9 and 10, there will probably never be a complete, definitve pack of all 10 Friday films. All in all, this is a slick package with a cool cover and art on the DVD's themselves. There may of been things that could of been done differently, or more people they could of tried to get in contact with, but in the end, this is special collection worth owning for any fan and the bonus features are out of this world!. Wether or not Jason will return with Freddy again, or stalk again in a new solo outing, this collection will always be right there and where Jason will always be at the ready.

reviewText: I know Paramount had promised us that we'd get the uncut versions of the "Friday the 13th" series months before they released this boxed-set on DVD and considering the fact that these are only the original R-rated cuts, a fair amount of fans were left disappointed. However, this is NOT as bad a deal as many people are making it out to be. After all, we DO still get all eight movies on four disks (two movies per disk), plenty of blood and gore [that would even satisfy the most hardcore gore-hound], and of course the main feature: JASON HIMSELF!! Here's a[n] short overview for all the movies included here:DISK ONE: "FRIDAY THE 13TH" PARTS I & IIPART I (1980, Run time: 95 minutes, Rated R)The one that started it all! In 1958, strange events begin to occur at the Camp Crystal Lake resort: a young boy drowns in the lake and two camp counselors are brutally murdered! 20 years later, the campsite is re-opened by a new generation of camp counselors. From there, we witness some of the most shocking (not to mention creative) death sequences ever caught on camera as they are all picked off one by one by an unseen killer!OVERALL: *****One of the BEST in the F13 series! It was also the movie that helped launch Kevin Bacon's movie career. (Who can ever forget the arrowhead through the throat scene?) The acting is also very well done, especially by actress Adrienne King, and the dark and disturbing atmosphere proves to be quite effective for a low-budget classic!PART II (1981, Run time: 86 minutes, Rated R)Once again, a new group of camp counselors experience a horrifying fate five years after the murders at Camp Crystal Lake. Relocated to a different campsite (but coincidently on the same lake), the carnage continues as a new killer lurks deep in the woods!OVERALL: ****Not as good as the original, but still packs plenty of scares! Such stars as Amy Steel and Paul Holt give pretty convincing performances, though they cannot hold a candle next to Adrienne King. This is also the first F13 to introduce us to everyone's favorite hockey-masked psycho, Jason Voorhees!DISK 2: "FRIDAY THE 13TH" Parts III & IVPART III (1982, Run time: 96 minutes, Rated R)Originally released as a 3-D feature in theaters, the DVD version [disappointingly] is only FLAT! Aside from this, the third installment is worth a look! Yet another set of camp counselors take a holiday at Camp Crystal Lake, but fall prey to the unstoppable killer known as Jason! This time, YOU are the victim!*****In my opinion, this is where everything really started picking up. It's also the movie where Jason first receives his hockey mask! Despite some so-so acting (e.g. Dana Kimmell's performance) and cheesy special effects, it is still an eye-popping (literally) thrill-ride! The musical score is also SUPERB!PART IV: THE FINAL CHAPTER (1984, Run time: 90 minutes, Rated R)After the events portrayed in Part 3, Jason's corpse is brought back to life and escapes from the town morgue! Elsewhere, a group of sex-crazed teens are on their way to the familiar Crystal Lake resort, but soon come face to face with the indestructible psycho! One by one, they meet some of the most shocking and twisted fate[s] yet! Now, it's up to whiz-kid, Tommy Jarvis (Corey Feldman) a young boy with a talent for making monster masks and makeup. Has Jason finally met his match?OVERALL: *****Considered to be a favorite among fans, which is not hard to understand why. The acting is good, the atmosphere is nice and creepy, and the gore effects are some of the greatest ever used in a horror film! (Kudos to makeup artist, Tom Savini) In addition, some of the BEST death sequences are executed well in this one! (The face-crushing shower scene is guaranteed to make you cringe) Of course, as we all know, this is NOT the 'Final' Friday!DISK 3: "Friday the 13th" Parts V & VIPart V: A NEW BEGINNING (1985, Run time: 92 minutes, Rated R)In this follow-up to `The Final Chapter, Tommy Jarvis (this time, played by John Shepherd) is all grown up and still traumatized by his experience as a child after brutally slaying the hockey masked murderer, Jason Voorhees! Although Jason is now believed to be dead, Tommy continues to be haunted by disturbing visions and fears that he is still alive and out there! It's seems to be his imagination at first, but it soon becomes reality! Jason's back, and this time he's after the troubled youths of an old country mental institute. But could this truly be the killer who everyone suspects, or is there something more to the story?OVERALL: ***Many fans claim this one to be the weakest in the series, which can be understandable. The script is a little silly and uneven at times, the acting is so-so (as with Part 2 & 3), and it isn't as scary as its previous titles. Still, it is quite interesting and worth a look, despite the so-called "imposter" twist at the end.PART VI: JASON LIVES (1986, Run time: 87 minutes, Rated R)One dark and stormy night, Tommy Jarvis (now played by Thom Mathews) drives down the road with an old friend in order to discover for himself if the legendary killer, Jason Voorhees is really dead. But after digging up the rotting corpse, lightning strikes the ground and instantly Jason is revived from his grave and escapes the cemetery! Now, more victims fall prey to the machete-wielding maniac and returns to where all the mayhem began at Camp Crystal Lake! (Re-named "Camp Forest Green") It's a race against time, as Tommy must put Jason back in his place, or die trying!OVERALL: ****While not exactly the best in the series, this is another favorite among fans. Compared to the previous installments, this is where things REALLY start to get campy! The acting is fine, the atmosphere is still scary, and the gore effects are still terrific! An improvement over Part 5!DISK 4: "Friday the 13th" Parts VII & VIIIPART VII: THE NEW BLOOD (1988, Run time: 88 minutes, Rated R)When a young psychic girl named Tina Shepard (Lar Park-Lincoln) and her widowed mother move back to their old home (which is ironically near Camp Crystal Lake) she accidentally frees Jason from his watery grave with her gift and the body count continues. Finally, Tina and Jason duke it out in an electrifying array of special effects and explosive entertainment!OVERALL: *****Another great entry to the series! Personally, this is one of my favorites and it's worth a watch just for the `Carrie VS. Jason' Plot alone. `The New Blood' may not be your usual `Friday' film, but for those who are looking for something different this time around rather than the usual find-the-counselor-and-kill routine will NOT be disappointed! The acting is dull, and the script is cheesy, but Jason is much stronger than he used to be this time around! It's also the first `Friday' that stars Kane Hodder as everyone's favorite hockey-masked killer!PART VIII: JASON TAKES MANHATTAN (1989, Run time: 100 minutes, Rated R)The last `Friday' film included in this boxed-set finds Jason leaving good ol' Camp Crystal Lake and stalking a group of High School graduates who are on their way aboard a luxury cruise to Manhattan! Now, Jason is painting the town red (literally), as he chases the teens through the mean streets of New York, tearing apart anyone who stands in his way! Can the masked psycho be stopped for good this time?!OVERALL: ****Not bad, though not too good either. The concept of Jason in the Big Apple is actually very interesting and fun to watch! As with Part 7, this one is also quite campy at times with the acting and script. However, there are even more awesome death scenes thrown in for your viewing pleasure! (The uppercut-and-decapitation-to-the-head scene is priceless!) Though not the last, it was followed by box-office flop, "Jason Goes to Hell" in 1993!BONUS DISK (Not Rated)Here we have a showcase of the special features for ALL eight of the movies:1. "THE FRIDAY THE 13TH CHRONICLES - 8-PART FEATURETTE"Spanning through all eight films, with cast and crew interviews (including Betsy Palmer and gore-effects wizard, Tom Savini) behind the popular horror franchise!2. "SECRETS GALORE BEHIND THE GORE - 3-PART FEATURETTE"A look behind the death sequences used in the movies with never-before-seen footage, drawings, and still photos that highlight the legacy of Jason Voorhees!3. "CRYSTAL LAKE VICTIMS TELL ALL!"Interviews with cast members from all the different films who explain their death scenes and how they feel with being stalked by Mr. Voorhees on camera!4. "TALES FROM THE CUTTING ROOM"This is the feature many fans have been screaming for: Uncut footage from some of the films that reveal even more blood curdling shock with Jason dispatching his victims (such as a longer death scene from Part I with Kevin Bacon) and rare, alternative scenes! This should appeal to ANY `Friday' fan!5. "FRIDAY ARTIFACTS AND COLLECTIBLES"Many different props and collectibles from the films set on display at a convention for the fans.6. "SCARY TRAILERS"Includes ALL of the theatrical trailers for Parts I-VIII!And there you have it!Indeed, this is a very good collection from the classic 80s slasher genre! Yes, it IS a bit of a letdown that we did not receive the uncut versions, but it's actually quite understandable, considering the fact that the deleted scenes' quality (seen in the `Cutting Room' feature) are kind of poor, while some of the other movies' footage is probably missing as well, or cannot be restored at all! Still, you gotta give credit where credit is due, and I say that the people at Paramount tried their best to bring us this Ultimate DVD set! With that in mind, these movies are fun and original and are worth watching again and again by all horror fans, young and old!

reviewText: I am a huge fan of the Friday the 13th Series. I grew up watching them, I had slumber parties that involved them, and as a camp counselor they were the ultimate movies to watch on the weekends and scare the heck out of the older cabins (We couldn't show them now, we would get sued by some parent for emotional trauma) When I purchased this 8 disk set I was ecstatic, maybe even giddy. I cannot say that I like every one of these movies, some I adore, some I can pick and chose the parts, and some are just plain stinkers, but as a total it all works out. So here is my review of each one;Part 1- The first and Best of the series. Why? Because it's the first, it's the quality of the film, it's the era in which it was made, and it was groundbreaking in the realm of slasher movies. We have Alice the innocent seeming camp counselor (what better location than at a camp!), who has such great hopes for the summer ahead and her hopes and friends and her job are all cut to pieces by mean Mrs. Vorhees(my favorite kill is Kevin Bacon, seeing the arrow and the arc of blood at the end is classic thanks to the Godfather of Gore Savini), we see Jason as a gnarly lake dweller who hates canoes at the end. I have to say Alice and her resounding screams stay in my head to this day.Part 2- The second Film and my second Favorite overall.  I love the heroine, the kills (my fave is of course the machete in the head of the wheelchair boy and down the steps he goes) Jason stomps around in his overalls and burlap bag causing bladders to empty and viewers to remark on his freaky thumbnail grooming. The whole film once again is at a camp, which makes for great locations and situations (mainly skinny dipping and horny counselors).Part 3- Ugh Its Jason 3-D, I really don't like this one all that much, The 3-D doesn't translate well onto the small screen, the characters are uber-cheesy (cheesier than usual I mean) we have the introduction of the hockey mask which is the only good thing about this installment. The kills aren't that stupendous, and you could tell that more time was spent on the 3-D effects than in the Gore.Part 4- The final Chapter. NOT. I have a love hate relationship with this one, I loved the movie, the settings, the kills, I Adore Crispin Glover he is just so goofy, I HATE the kid, cant stand Corey Feldman in this, Horrible casting, I felt like I was waiting for him to make Jason do the Truffle Shuffle (he was doing Goonies at the same time and I think he got the characters mixed up at times)Part 5- The switcharoo Jason one, There were some really scary parts in this like Tommie's bald spot, the girl singing to the guy taking a dump, the punk rock girl listening to jazz and doing the robot, oh and the wet t-shirt contest on the school counselor. Revenge for a son he abandoned then was murdered is the premise for the killer, confusing but hey it's not up for an Oscar. There is a lot of good kills, the belt, the flare, the snipping shears, I would give this 7 out of 10 stars.Part 6- My Third Favorite Overall in the series, the main guy a grown up Tommy Jarvis played by Return of the Living dead alumni Thom Maxwell, Its So clever and funny and original (yes original in the "atmosphere" of the series) I love the story, the locations (back to camp crystal lake we go) the kids (best line of the movie "so what WERE you going to be when you grew up" as they hide from Jason) Best kill is the dude in the Winnebago ( who also has a cameo in the original Karate Kid beach scene)Part 7-  What could have been a good installment, turns out to be the most boring of the bunch. We are at crystal lake, there are teenagers, but there is no real tension. A telekinetic chick (who in the special features looks like she floated too many Twinkies into her mouth) kills her father on the dock (and they don't find his body? but when he grabs jason he looks like he just freaking died?) Years later her mother and her therapist (Bernie, from Weekend at Bernie's!) go out to the spot again to deal with her anger. She brings back Jason from the watery grave, and he kills everyone of course, no great kills, in fact I think they are downright lazy in that department, the "new" Jason covered in chains and his spine showing looks ridiculous and too "busy" what the heck was wrong with the blue jumpsuit? I know he is supposed to be submerged for 10 years, but the clothes looked like my niece was trying to make snowflakes out of paper for Christmas. Kane Hodder, not that great of a Jason, and they guy is just strange in the interviews,Part 9- Jason takes Manhattan...in the last minute. It should have been "Jason gets Seasick" and have him killing Isaac Washington and Gopher. This is my least favorite of the Lot. It's so flimsily put together and so obviously there to just make money, not to add artistic nuances or intrigue to the whole series. Jason Pilots a friggin Yacht to the harbor? They completely changed the look of the young Jason drowning, at least stick to what you know! The kills are retarded, and when they finally get to "Manhattan" or Canada whatever, they drop the ball completely. Seeing half naked drowned Jason in his skivvies was a horrible ending to Paramount's finishing touch on Friday the 13th.The extra Features are totally worth watching; just seeing the cast members, and Tom Savini and all the directors and all the Jason's was really worth it. I like the Plug for Tom Savinis School that was brilliant of him. All in all, a great series to own, too bad it keeps going with New Line, but it only gets worse from this point.

reviewText: Paramount has always treated the Friday the 13th movies like an unwanted child. Despite the impressive box-office numbers that it earned for the studio during the 80's, they always seemed to be embarassed by it. By the 90's, they had its rights to the more slasher-friendly New Line Cinema who were already making nice bank off the "Nightmare On Elm Street" series though Paramount still held claim to the video rights to the first eight "Friday" films. The first DVD releases for these titles were noticeably short on extras and fans were begging for updated versions. Paramount answered the calls of the fans but in typical fashion, they rushed to put out a half-baked deluxe package. Originally rumored to feature the uncut versions of all eight films, the final product puts the movies together (two on each disc) over four discs with a fifth disc featuring bonus material. The deleted scenes are in pretty poor quality and aside from the unedited death sequences in "Part VII", there isn't much to write home about. There are commentary tracks for four of the films (III, VI, VII, VIII) and cast interviews for each movie with Corey Feldman, Tom Savini, Kane Hodder, and others. Not a bad collection but one can't help feeling short-changed when comparing the original plan for this boxed set with the end result.

reviewText: From Crystal Lake to Manhattan features the first 8 movies in the series put out by Paramount Pictures. I know a lot of fans were excited about the set since the previous DVDs by Paramount had no extras except for trailers, which they didn't even have for the last 2. Jason Lives we only got a teaser.  As for the DVDs we get 2 movies per disc, which honestly I don't care for. The cases are the slim ones and personally I don't like them.The movies themselves are cut for the R-Rating. Fans have wanted uncut versions, but Paramount still refuses. They claim poor sales, but yet they still put out a boxed set so why not just have them uncut? The only differences are Friday the 13th Part III and Friday the 13th Part 6-8 have audio commentaries. While the tracks are pretty good it's really nothing to get excited about.The original Friday the 13th is actually cut, well sort of. The single disc DVD has the uncut death of Annie. Some how it slipped in. The Boxed Set has the true R-rated version of Annie's death. It's only cut by a couple of seconds. No blood is missing only the reaction shot is shorter. It's very easy for it to go unnoticed.The bonus disc is fairly decent, but honestly it does lack a bit. The Friday the 13th Chronicles is a feature with interview about all 8 installments. The first Friday the 13th is the longest with about 22-min and rest run at about 14-min with A New Beginning only being about 5-min, which all it does is bring up the ending of The Final Chapter and it was left open for something different in Part V.While the interviews are interesting the info we learn isn't anything special. Any movie geek will already know how the F/X was done. It's good to see some of the actors discussing the movies they did, but when all is said and done it's a good feature, but nothing amazing.The 3-part feature Secrets Galore, Behind the Gore was interesting, but again this is all stuff most fans probably already knew. Like the Friday the 13th Chronicles a good feature, but nothing amazing. Crystal Lake Victims Tell all seems like it was just stuff cut from the Friday the 13th Chronicles. So, once again good feature, but nothing great.  Bottom line is you see once and well odds are that is enough. Maybe in time you'll revisit, but it's nothing all that major.Tales from the Cutting Room floor is probably the best feature, but poorly handled. When we see the extra gore for the original and 6th part we get a small box with the R-cut and another small box with the uncut.  Parts 2 & 3 have nothing, The Final Chapter has 2-cut scenes (not gore scenes). A New Beginning & Jason Takes Manhattan have nothing. Come Paramount I'm sure you could have dug up something. I know part 2 suffered some cuts and Part III has some cut gore scenes and some scenes deleted from the final cut.  They least they could have done is put a little something on their.  The saving grace is The New Blood. The quality is poor, but that is understandable since it wasn't reasserted.My question is this, since Paramount obviously has the footage why not just put them in the films??? In particular The New Blood since the edits made do take away from the kill scenes. It would have been nice if they put them back in the first and 6th films as well, but even cut they don't take away from the death scenes where as the cuts really put a damper on the death scenes in The New Blood.We also have Friday artifacts and collectibles, which isn't anything really all that good and finally the trailers for all 8 films except Jason Lives, which only has the teaser just like the original DVD.Overall the set is decent plain and simple. What could have been one of the best DVD sets turns into something that is average at best. I'm sure die hard fans like myself will still be some what pleased, but at the end of the day it's nothing to get excited about.  If you have the original DVDs upgrading isn't really needed. If you have the extra cash and there isn't anything you really want then I would say give it a shot. But if you have the original DVDs I would say save the money and buy other DVDs.For those who do not own the films I would say buy the set, since it will be cheaper.

Parts 1 through 5 are presented in Dolby Digital Mono, Parts 6 and 8 get surround capabilities with Dolby Sourround 2.0 tracks(Described as Dolby Ultra-Surround on the disc cover) and part 7 features both Dolby Digital 5.1 and Dolby Surround 2.0 tracks. The Mono tracks concentrate the entire sound field at the center channel. At times, it sounds one-dimensional but overall, it does a competent job of converying a scary atmosphere throughout. One thing that I took notice was the fact that the Mono audio track actually makes the films more convinving, like a Saturday night horror flick as the drive-in, watching classic Universal black and white horror movies. Part 6 and 8 expand the sound field further and both films sound much better than Mono tracks on the first five movies. As for the Dolby Digital 5.1 audio track on Part 7, the aural experience is improved but I don't feel that the film takes full advantage of the technology. The surround channels are used mainly for environmental surrounds and the sudden musical cues that accompany some of the scarier scenes. Also available are French Dolby Digital Mono tracks on all the films.SPECIAL FEATURES:The special features included in this box set will make or break the success of this release. Anyone looking o upgrade their single disc bare-bones versions will ultimately base their pruchasing decision on whether the bonus features are worth the money extra money. As the version of the movies included here are the exact same ones as before without any noticeable changes to video and audio quality, the only thin left to consider are the bonus features. First, there are a total of four audio commentaries, one each for Parts 3,6,7, and 8. It is too bad that there is no commentary track on the first film. Part 3's commentary features Peter Bracke,Dana Kimmel,Richard Brooker,Larry Zerner and Paul Kratka. As some of you may know, Peter Bracke is the editor of the [...]website. Here he acts as a kind of moderator or interviewer,posing questions to the four cast member in attendance. Bracke does a very good job at asking the right questions and you can at once sense that he came to the recording session fully prepared. TI am not a very big fan of audio commentaries but this one turned out to bequite fun one to listen to. Part 6 happens to my favorite of the eight films here. The audio commentary track here features a solo session with writer/director Tom McLoughlin and I am glad it is a good one. The next commentary is on Part 7 which features director John Carl Buechler and the actor who plays Jason, Kane Hodder.Finally on the last film part 8 the audio commentary track features writer/director Rob Hedden. Hdden provides great information about the film, especially budget constraints that could have made the film better. This is perhaps the weakest commentary track as Hedden has a tendency to describe the action on the screen instead of volunteering information about the making of it.Okay, now that we are done with the four audio commentaries,let's move on to the bonus features on the separate bonus materoal disc, also called Killer Extras. The most extensive and engrossing feature is titles The friday the 13th Chronicles, an 8 part set that devotes one part for each film in chronological order. On the first part which is the longest, director Sean Cunnigham introduces the audience to the series and proceeds to talk about the production details of the first film and how he made the title in mind before he even had a script. The next feature is called Secrets Galore Behind the Gore. It talks about how they made the death scenes look as real as possible. It talks about the kills in Part 1,4,and7. This was really intersting to watch.Then there is a section called Tales from the Cutting Room. It contains deleted,extended and alternate material from Part 1,4,6,7. I think alot of fans have been waiting to watch all the deleted scenes. Next feature is titled Crystal Lake victims Tell ALL! This is a featurette where Jason's victims come forward to talk about their experiences working on the various films. Many of them talk about the fun they had and also provide some interesting anecdotes. Overall, this is quite a fun feature to sit through. Then we have Friday Artifacts and Collectibles, this is where the various directors and some fans show off their collection of Friday teh 13Th memorabilia.The last thing in this box set is the trailers for all of the films,except for part 6 which is a teaser. All the five discs are house in THINpak cases, the same ones that Paramount is using for their box set releases of classic television series like Happy Days. The external box that holds five DVD cases is quite attractive and sturdy, featuring and embossed images of Jason's infamous hockey mask in the front.IMAGE:I give it 6 stars out of 10.SOUND: I give it 5 stars out of 10.SPECIAL FEATURES: I give it 9 stars out of 10.

reviewText: Throughout the 1980's, horror fans worldwide would come to know one title that would remain infamous- Friday the 13th. Starting with a successful murder mystery in 1980 and ending with a blood and guts campy horror flick in 1989, "Friday the 13th" started a revolution of horror films and continued what "Halloween" had started in 1978. The films all were based around a group of people who were stalked and, for about 90% of those stalked, they were killed, and for about 98% of those killed, they were killed in gruesome ways. "Friday the 13th" was a movie series that many could say were responsible for the craze of 80's slasher flicks, such as the "Nightmare on Elm Street" series, "Child's Play", "Sleepaway Camp", "Valentine's Day", "The Evil Dead", and many, many, many more. Now, for the first time, Paramount Pictures is releasing a DVD Box Set which includes the first eight films that they distributed, and loads of extras. The series has a good portion of decent horror films, a few very bad horror films, and it has an interesting array of extras which fans may hate or love. It's a toss of the dice to whether you will want to own this killer box set, but for the most part, it'll be worth the buy.First, there were a few good, standard, and entertaining horror films in this box set. "Friday the 13th" would be the first in the series. Released in 1980, the film focuses around a group of camp councilors who are stalked by an unknown killer. Filmed in similar ways to "Halloween", "Friday the 13th" isn't really scary, but a good amount of thrills and gore for those crazy horror buffs out there. This is one of the best in the series, and even spawned a stunning 7 sequels, plus related films including "Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday" (1994), "Jason X" (2002), and "Freddy vs. Jason" (2003). Next in the series comes 1981's sleeper hit, "Friday the 13th Part 2", which is where the series really took off. Here, the infamous serial killer Jason Voorhees is introduced wearing a sack or bag over his head. Here, Jason follows in his deranged mother's footsteps and kills off a bunch of camp councilors in training. This film has scary and suspenseful, and is the best in the series, one that mostly everyone will enjoy. Jason then takes a turn in "Friday the 13th Part 3", where the killer gets his trademark hockey mask and while wearing his new mask, he kills a group of friends on a vacation at Camp Crystal Lake. It's scary but goofy, and has a likable feel to it. The film will bring you straight to the beginning of the 80's, especially 1982, which was when the movie was released. The series still isn't over, however, because Jason, who is still alive and still has the hockey mask, goes back to his old ways once again and begins to kill at a house filled with partying teenagers and even strikes at a peaceful family next door in 1984's "Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter". Although not as creepy or fun as the past films, this movie has more deaths, more gore, and more Jason. Oh, and don't listen to the title, we're far from the final chapter (who knows what the final chapter will be). Skipping over the awful 5th installment, we are brought to 1986's "Friday the 13th Part VI: Jason Lives", where Tommy Jarvis, from "The Final Chapter" battles Jason once again, who has been brought back to life by Tommy's own doing. We also get to see a new, stylized Crystal Lake, which has reopened since the first "Friday's" events. This flick, aside from being very gory, is also campy and funny, and a good installment to the series. Jason comes back with a bang. Then the last 'good' "Friday" film is brought in 1988 with "Friday the 13th Part VII: The New Blood". This movie is not particularly 'good', but it is entertaining. There's a lot of gore, a lot of death, some funny moments, some really funny hair, but it isn't chilling like the rest. It's not bad, but there are better horror films of the time. Until 2003's "Freddy vs. Jason", this is the last film with Jason Voorhees that actually has some decent acting and story. Those are the installments in the series that are worth while, and they are defiantly worth the buy of the box set.Second, in every series, there has to be a few stinkers that really aren't needed parts of the series and you can do without, plus enjoy the other movies just as much. 1985's "Friday the 13th Part V: A New Beginning" and 1989's "Friday the 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan" are among those in the "Friday the 13th" series. "A New Beginning" takes place between "The Final Chapter" and "Jason Lives", and hate to spoil the surprise to those of you who haven't seen it, but there's no Jason here. It seems as if there is, but there really isn't. This movie is really bad in every aspect. The story, the ending, the acting, the script- just everything (except that guys might enjoy watching a bunch of nude girls or girls in soaking wet T-shirts). "A New Beginning" also has every cliché in the book- you know who's dead from the moment you see them. The only fun of watching this movie would be to see the funky dancing from 1985, which really isn't that good, but it sure is funny. "Jason Takes Manhattan" is the infamous installment where, well, Jason takes Manhattan. It comes after "The New Blood", and it is a little better than "A New Beginning", but the story is just so stupid. Even though you can completely block out the events of "A New Beginning", you can't do that here. If you watch "Jason Goes to Hell" (which is not included in this box set due to the fact that New Line released it and not Paramount), you will see that "Jason Takes Manhattan" is apart of the series. It is a fun movie to watch, and it worth the watch. It is not scary, but the music and styles are just so... 80's. It's perfect for a good laugh and a flash to the past, since it captures the mood of the 80's perfectly. The writing and story however can get slashed. It has Jason come back from the dead, hitch a ride on a ship from Crystal Lake to Manhattan, where he most of the passenger's on the ship, and then follows the survivors to Manhattan. The main flaw here is Jason walking around time square, and no one noticing him. Also, millions of people are in New York and the survivor's can't get any help. Plus, in the other films Jason had some sort of reason to kill these people (even if the reasons were pretty weak). Here he just kills. This movie will deliver the best gore in the series, and the most deaths in possibly the whole series. Overall, you can skip right over "A New Beginning" but "Jason Takes Manhattan" might be good for a laugh or something since it is more connected to the series.Last, people might not like extras provided in the series. The main thing people won't like is that none of the films are uncut, and from what Paramount is saying about the uncut versions being lost, it looks like we will never see any of them uncut. I myself have heard that they are better uncut, but who knows. I would have also liked to maybe have "Friday the 13th 3" presented in 3D, like it originally was, but I'm not sure if it's possible or not on a television screen. The last thing that will tick people off is that there are two movies per disk, making four disks. That's a little cheap of paramount, since each film deserves its own disk. There are commentaries on "Friday the 13th Part 3", "Friday the 13th: The Final Chapter", "Friday the 13th Part VI: Jason Lives", and "Friday the 13th Part VII: The New Blood". A fifth disk will be presented with the series extras, including a documentary on the history of the "Friday the 13th" franchise, and a look at Jason Voorhees and his many kills. That series documentary will be feature length and will hopefully as detailed as the feature length "Halloween: A Cut Above the Rest" (as seen on the "Halloween H25" DVD) or "Chainsaw Redux: Making a Massacre" (as seen on "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (2003) DVD). There is a featurette called "Where are they Now" where the actors of the films are shown on basically, where are they now and what have they done since their time on "Friday the 13th". There is another featurette which looks at the props and, hopefully, the sets of the films and how makeup artists designed their death sequences. Trailers for all the movies are presented, except for "Jason Lives", which has a teaser trailer replace it. The extras sound pretty good, even though I am disappointed that there are not commentaries and interviews for every film. They should also have a 9 disk DVD box set, with one movie per disk plus the bonus disk.Overall, this box set sounds okay. It's not what the fans have been screaming for, but it'll do, until they can create an ultimate box set where the other films (the ones by New Line) are presented as well. At least there is a box set where you can own these films all together. Horror fans are still waiting for the highly anticipated "Halloween: The DVD Box Set" to come out. With a good amount of entertaining features, six fun films to watch, and even with two somewhat lousy films, they can still be entertaining. Go from your home to the nearest place where they will sell "From Crystal Lake to Manhattan: The Friday the 13th Box Set". Still hoping for "From Crystal Lake to Manhattan, from Hell to Space: The Ultimate Friday the 13th Box Set" to come out. But for now, this will do.

reviewText: I remember the first time I saw "Friday the 13th" on TV as a child (uncut), it was on Halloween night in 1983 (still remember the year) and it scared the living daylights out of me. They aired "Part II" the following night and let me just say that I slept with my parents for the remainder of the week. Today I am an enthusiastic horror film fan and several of these films hold sentimental value. Although they are by no means "masterpieces" and many film-buff/critics have never considered any of these films to be true "classics" (like the original "Halloween" and "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre"), these blood-soaked chillers have managed to scare the life out of millions of people world-wide and Jason Voorhees has become as famous as Ronald McDonald and Mickey Mouse.In my opinion, the first four offerings are the best in the series. All the films share pretty much the same story; Young, attractive camp counselors being stalked and brutally slaughtered by a homicidal maniac out for revenge. The original 1980 film, "Friday The 13th" is the best in the series due largely for its creative, cleverly executed murder sequences. It also provides a tremendous amount of suspense, gore and its climactic finale is riveting. The first sequel, "Friday The 13th: Part II", follows the same formula. Like its predecessor, it offers loads of suspense and introduces us to the masked killer known throughout the world as Jason. In this installment however, he is devoid of his trademark hockey mask, instead he uses a one-eyed sack to cover his deformity. The infamous hockey mask is introduced in "Friday The 13th: Part III". This third installment features some very inventive executions and during its theatrical run, was shown in 3-D. Since no 3-D glasses are included in this package and "Part III" was intended to be seen in 3-D, many of the scenes look silly, losing much of its original appeal. Despite this, the second sequel is a worthy addition to the franchise. Like the previous 2 films, it's gory good fun, lacking in performances but tension and dread are in abundance. It's definitely light years ahead of the ones that were to follow. In 1984, "Friday The 13th: The Final Chapter" was unleashed and it was intended to be the last entry in this bloody saga. In my opinion, "The Final Chapter" is one of the (if not "the") grisliest of them all. The murder sequences are brutally explicit and this follow-up marked the last time Jason was truly frightening. In the episodes that were to follow, Jason would become more of a caricature, an everlasting walking dead man with dirty clothes, wielding an axe or a machete and possessing super human strength. What made the later films even more disappointing is that, despite having greater body counts, they became less explicit with minimal gore, no scare logic and offered virtually no suspense. I am assuming the censors had something to do with this.The worst entry in the franchise is "Friday the 13th Part V: A New Beginning". Despite having an engaging opening, the film never manages to captivate and it looses steam early on. The murder sequences are also disappointing; lacking gore and imagination and as you may already know (SPOILER WARNING), Jason is not even the killer. The film may have worked had it been better directed. The end result is as scary as an episode of "Hells Kitchen" and no where near as exciting. Jason was finally resurrected in the following chapter ingeniously titled "Friday The 13th  Part VI: Jason Lives". Although it's a major improvement over "Part V", it lacks the tension of the earlier films. Nevertheless, "Part VI" does have Jennifer Cooke, definitely one of the most attractive blondes to ever step foot on Crystal Lake (despite her very 80's attire and hair-do). "Friday The 13th Part VII: The New Blood" follows and it's clearly evident in this film that the writers had run out of fresh ideas. This time around, Jason is put up against Tina, a young, troubled blonde with telekinesis. Although this installment has its fans, I am not one of them. There is a lot of slaughter on display but most of the murder sequences are bloodless (who wants that?). As bad as "Part VII" is, "Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan" is even worse. First of all, the title is misleading because most of the murders take place aboard a cruise ship which means most of Jason's victims are "hacked up" even before they set foot in New York. Like the previous film, the murders displayed in "Part VIII" are, for the most part, bloodless and lack-luster which will disappoint gore-hounds and those expecting an exciting, blood-soaked thrill-ride.A bonus DVD is included which offers some interesting material. There is an interesting 8-Part Featurette -"The Friday the 13th Chronicles" which has several interviews by cast members; Adrienne King, Betsy Palmer, Corey Feldman, Amy Steele and make-up artist Tom Savini. There are also deleted scenes, trailers, a 3-Part Featurette-"Behind the Gore" and much more.I must admit that I am not a big fan of the whole "2 films per 1 DVD" type packaging because it makes it appear that not much thought goes into the production. It seems rushed and of lower quality when compared to other DVD collecters editions (The "Alien Quadrilogy" comes to mind). With that said, die-hard (no pun intended) fans should be impressed by this 5-Disc DVD Collection. The films are all immaculately transferred and the extras are interesting enough to keep you watching. Definitely a must-have for horror film fans everywhere.
summary: The Most Famous Splatter Films Ever Made Finally Released in a Much Awaited But Sloppily Made Box-Set.

reviewText: First off:  I loved it!Friday the 13...One of the most influential horror series in history.  One of the most influential film series in general.  Hockey Mask = Jason, no questions asked.  Jason has become an entertainment icon because of how awsome these movies are on average and how fun they are to watch.  I'll give you my short ratings and reviews of the movies in this collection.Disc 1:- Friday the 13th (3.5/5) -First in the series.  If you haven't seen it, I won't give it away, but don't be dissapointed because there are 9 more movies in the series to make up for it if you are.  Kevin Bacon's appearance is also fun in this simple little slasher movie.- Friday the 13th - Part 2 (3.5/5) -Yes, It's better than the first.  Jason is pretty creepy the way he's presented.  Gradually, more of him is revealed throughout the movie.  The characters are alot more entertaining this time around, although too many of them make a departure at the beginning without ever confronting Jason, but the ones that do fall to him are likeable enough to show that the filmmakers did a good job in the character department.Disc 2:- Friday the 13th - Part III (3.5/5) -Filmed in 3D with some obvious 3D shots that are still in 2D.  Too bad, this would be an awsome movie in 3D.  Anyway, it's just about as entertaining as the 2nd film, with probably the most memorable character in the first three films: Shelly.  This is the movie where Jason finally gets his hockey mask.- Friday the 13th - The Final Chapter (4/5) -This is a great movie.  It's possible that you don't even have to be a horror fan to enjoy it, you just might not like it as much.  The story is interesting, forusing equally on Corey Feldman, the young Tommy Jarvis, and the other red-shirt killables including Crispin Glover, who's probably the most entertaining character in the movie.Disc 3:- Friday the 13th - Part V: A New Beginning (2/5) -As I said earlier, these movies are great *on average*.  This is the movie that accomplished that.  No doubt, the most cheesy/corny film in the series, is the worst one.  I'd like to know what were going through the filmmaker's heads when they made this movie, especially following the greatness of The Final Chapter.- Friday the 13th - Part VI: Jason Lives (4/5) -My favorite and arguably the best film in the series.  Tom McLoughlin's writing and direction is hilarious and breaths fresh air into the series after Part V, a total dissapointment.  This might be the most tame in the series.  I don't believe there's any nudity, although there is the traditional naughty behavior that is a trademark of the series.  It's good to see that McLoughlin saw the comedy potential of the series, and took the opportunity to make the best movie.Disc 4:- Friday the 13th - Part VII: The New Blood (3.5/5) -Featuring Kane Hodder for the first time playing Jason, this film probably has the best Jason design in the series.  He looks pretty beaten up with exposed bones and a damaged mask.  His final exposed face is pretty awsome and makes him seem like more of a zombie.  The whole deal about the telekenetic girl and everything isn't as bad as it sounds and makes for some pretty cool moments in the film and one of the better movies in the series.- Friday the 13th - Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan (3/5) -2nd worst movie in the series.  I was debating with myself for a while whether or not I actually liked this movie, but in the end I realized that it was entertaining enough for me to consider it good.  Don't get me wrong though, this movie makes no sense.  Jason appears in places in such short ammount of time that it becomes physically impossible, like how he made it from a sinking ship to the dock, but that's all been said before.  If this movie would've had more money from Paramount to work with, it would've ended up being alot better no doubt.Disc 5:- The Friday the 13th Chronicles -An 8 part documentary covering the making of each film.  Not much is really said about Part V.  Surprise.- Secrets Galore Behind the Gore -Tom Savini and John Carl Buechler discuss the special effects they did for the kills in the movies and Tom Savini gives us a taste of his make-up school.- Crystal Lake Victims Tell All! -Extra interviws with members of the cast.- Tales From the Cutting Room -A series of deleted scenes and extra carnage that was cut out of Part VII.  John Carl Buechler and Kan Hodder talk over the audio of the Part VII scenes which include the famous sleeping bag death which was cut down from being swung 6 times into the tree, to 1.- Friday Artifacts and Collectibles -A short tidbit showing set pieces and props that various people have.NOTE:Part 3,6,7, and 8 include commentaries.This is a great set featuring great movies that were made, for the most part, by some really cool people.  Horror fans should basically have already seen these, I just recently saw them and I can't believe I went so long without.Enjoy.

reviewText: Friday the 13th is a contreversial horror franchise. It always has been, and it probably always will be. People tend to either fall on one side of the fence; either you love it or you hate. I myself have always been a fan of the gory slashers, and if you are a fan of the series, this box set was made for you. The set includes all the Paramount licensed films, 1-8 (Jason Goes To Hell, Jason X and Freddy Vs Jason are licensed to New Line Cinema, so they weren't included), and if you haven't seen any of the films in a while, this is a great way to brush up on some of your Friday the 13th history, and revisit some fond moments you had in the past.So first there are the movies, which themselves are great. While I'm still partial to the first four films of the series, but as a fan I still enjoy them all. Most people know the Plot lines of the movies, and if you don't you can probably look on a different review and find plot synopsis' for any of the movies. Along with each movie you get Director commentary, which is kind of cool to hear while watching the movie. The real treat of the box seat though, is the extras disk which is included along with the eight movies. The disk contains featurettes for each of the eight films, getting comments from the director and interviews with cast members and technicians who worked on the movie sets. Theres also a "Three part" secrets behind the gore featurette, which takes you inside the killings of the movies, a "Crystal Lake Victims Tell All" segment, which has interviews with some of Jason's victims, a "Tales From The Cutting Room" feature, which is deleted scenes and original footage from many of the movies, a "Friday Artifacts and Collectibles" segment which gives you an inside look at some of the props used in the movies, and finally "Scary Trailers", which has trailers for the eight films. Overall it's really entertaining to watch, and you get a lot for you money on this one, because it's not just some 10 mintues bonus footage thing that's tacked on at the end or production. This is the real deal for Friday The 13th Fans. This combined with the original eight movies, is more than enough reason to pick this is, especially if you're a fan of the series.I love the fact that Paramount finally released a box set of the first 8 movies. It has been a long time coming. It's a great place to get all the movies for one low price (especially if you don't own any of them yet) and to get some behind the scenes information about the series. If you were never a fan of the series, then this box set is probably not going to convert you, so it's not recommended to just the casual viewers. This is definitely a box set made for the fans, and I couldn't be happier that it was finally released. Do yourself a favor and revisit all the good (or bad and bloody) memories you had with Jason, and Crystal. This box set is the perfect opportunity to do so.

reviewText: PLOT:I. Friday The 13th (1980): The film begins at Camp Crystal Lake in 1958. Two teenage counselors sneak into a room to have sex, but before they can undress, a mysterious figure murders them both. The film then fast forwards to Crystal Lake in 1979. A young girl named Annie (Robbi Morgan) enters the Crystal Lake diner and asks for directions to the camp, much to the shock of the diner patrons, who inform Annie that the camp has been closed for over two decades. Local lore holds that the campground is cursed, in addition to the murders, a young boy drowned in 1957. After the two counselors were murdered in 1958, several attempts were made to reopen the camp, all unsuccessful, due to a series of bizarre occurrences (unexplained fires, and another year, water contamination). Annie writes off these events as superstition and coincidence. She hitches a ride with a truck driver, who drops her off a few miles from the camp after he suggests that Annie return home and not work at the allegedly "cursed" camp. Meanwhile, the camp is getting fixed up by the owner Steve Christie (Peter Brouwer). The rest of the counselors soon arrive; they are Ned (Mark Nelson), Jack (Kevin Bacon), Bill (Harry Crosby), Marcie (Jeannine Taylor), Alice (Adrienne King), and Brenda (Laurie Bartram). Steve tells the counselors that he needs to run errands in town and leaves the counselors to continue camp repairs. Later on, Annie (who is still walking to the camp on foot) is picked up by an unseen person in a Jeep. Annie appears to be making a casual, if somewhat one-sided conversation with the driver. Eventually Annie notices that they have passed the turn-off road to Camp Crystal Lake. Annie politely suggests they stop and turn around, only to be disregarded by the driver, who in turn speeds past the camp and deeper into the forest. When the driver still won't respond to Annie's frightened cries to stop, Annie jumps from the vehicle, wounding her leg. She limps away into the woods, but is cornered by the driver of the Jeep, who violently slashes her throat. Who could the driver be and does he/she have any connection to the Camp Crystal Lake curse?II. Friday The 13th Part 2 (1981): The film begins 2 months after the first film. Alice (Adrienne King), the lone survivor of Mrs. Voorhees' killing spree, is now recovering in her apartment. She goes to open her refrigerator, only to find Mrs. Voorhees' decapitated head inside. She screams and is suddenly killed by an unseen figure. Five years later, a new group of teenage counselors prepare to open up a new camp in Crystal Lake. During the preparation for the opening, some strange things start to happen and the counselors start getting murdered off by a strange figure wearing a burlap sack as a mask. If Mrs. Voorhees is dead, then who is this masked figure and what connection does he have to her?III. Friday The 13th Part 3 (1982): The film picks up immediately after the end of Part 2. After Jason (now played by Richard Brooker) was stabbed in the shoulder by Ginny (Amy Steel), he didn't die. He left his cabin and stole a new pair of clothes from a roadside general store, and later killed the owner and his wife. Meanwhile, a group of teenagers are setting out to spend the weekend at a family-owned Crystal Lake cabin. The party includes Chris (Dana Kimmell), whose family owns the cabin,  Chris' boyfriend Rick (Paul Kratka), the pregnant Debbie (Tracie Savage) and her boyfriend Andy (Jeffrey Rogers), the bong-tokin' Chuck (David Katims) and Chili (Rachel Howard), Vera (Catherine Parks), and Shelly (Larry Zerner), an overweight kid given to gruesome pranks. After the group moves into the cabin, Vera and Shelley go into town to get some supplies at a general store. Once at the store, the two are confronted by a trio of bikers and Shelly drives into their motorcycles. The bikers, Ali (Nick Savage), Loco (Kevin O'Brien) and Fox (Gloria Charles), make their way to the cabin for retribution, where they siphon the gas from the van to burn down the barn. Before that happens, though, they're killed by Jason. Chris and her friends are the next target for Jason's murdering spree.IV. Friday The 13th: The Final Chapter (1984): Picking up immediately where Part 3 left off, police and paramedics are now cleaning up Jason Voorhees' (now played by Ted White) mess at Chris's family cabin. Jason's body, still with an axe embedded in his forehead, is put on a stretcher and sent to the morgue. Once delivered to the morgue, the superhuman killer rises again and kills an attendant and a nurse. He then begins to make his way back to Crystal Lake. A group of friends have rented a house on Crystal Lake. They are Paul (Alan Hayes), Samantha (Judie Aronson), Sara (Barbara Howard), Doug (Peter Barton), Ted (Lawrence Monoson) and Jimmy (Crispin Glover). The cabin next to the rented house is lived in by Mrs. Jarvis (Joan Freeman), her teenaged daughter Trish (Kimberly Beck), her twelve-year-old son Tommy (Corey Feldman), and their dog, Gordon. The group later meets Trish, Tommy and Gordon. The next day the group befriends twins Tina and Terri (Camilla and Carey More), who live in the area, and they all go skinny-dipping at Crystal Point. Trish and Tommy, driving by, stop to see who's at Crystal Point and the group invites Trish to a party that night. Trish's car breaks down a bit further along the road, and they are helped by Rob (Erich Anderson), a hiker with mysterious reasons for visiting Crystal Lake, who soon becomes good friends with Trish and Tommy, and camps out in their yard. The Crystal Lake setting seems like the ideal place for a nice relaxing vacation, little do the teeneagers know that they are about to get a little visit from Jason Voorhees.V. Friday The 13th Part V: A New Beginning (1985): Twelve year-old Tommy Jarvis (Corey Feldman) walks through the woods in the pouring rain to visit Jason's tombstone, just so he can make sure that the masked maniac is really dead. Suddenly he hears two men coming, so he hides in the bushes. The two men arrive at Jason's grave and start digging it up. They open up the coffin and find Jason's body covered in worms. Suddenly he wakes up and kills both of them. Jason (now played by Tom Morga) senses that someone is watching him and starts to pursue Tommy. Suddenly Tommy wakes up from this bad dream. Some years have passed since the events of The Final Chapter and Tommy (now played by John Shepherd) is an older teenager being transferred from the Unger Institute of Mental Health to the Pinehurst home for troubled teens. He has been traumatized ever since he killed Jason. At the home, he meets Pam Roberts (Melanie Kinnaman), the assistant director, and Dr. Matthew Letter (Richard Young). He later meets other residents: "Reggie the Reckless" (Shavar Ross), his employee grandfather George (Vernon Washington), Eddie (John Robert Dixon), Tina (Debi Sue Voorhees), Joey (Dominck Brascia), Violet (Tiffany Helm), Robin (Juliette Cummins), and Vic (Mark Venturini). Tommy knows that Jason is dead and buried, but he still has hallucinations about him and he sees him everywhere. One day, Joey pesters Vic until he snaps and kills Joey with an axe in a fit of rage. Vic is arrested and ambulance attendants Duke Johnson (Caskey Swaim) and Roy Burns (Dick Wieand) come and take Joey's body away. Soon after, murders start occuring in the area. Could Jason Voorhees be the culprit? No way; Tommy watched him die. Jason may have had superhuman strength, but no one could survive a machete chop in the skull, or could they?VI. Friday The 13th Part VI: Jason Lives (1986): A year has passed since the events of A New Beginning. Tommy Jarvis (now played by Thom Matthews) is driving back to Crystal Lake (now renamed Forest Green) with his friend Allen (Ron Palillo). Tommy intends to go to the cemetery, dig up Jason's grave, and cremate it into ashes so he knows that there is no chance in Hell that Jason can ever harm anyone again. The two dig up the grave and Tommy opens the coffin. Tommy sees Jason's body rotting and covered with maggots. The sight of the body sends Tommy into a fury and he grabs a steel rod and drives it into the corpse. Suddenly a bolt of lightning hits the rod and brings Jason (now played by C.J. Graham) back to life. Allen is killed trying to save Tommy, who manages to escape. The terrified young man rushes to Sheriff Garris' (David Kagen) office and warns him that Jason is alive. But the lawman recognizes Tommy and knowing that he has been under psychiatric care since killing Jason, Garris ignores Tommy's ravings and throws him in jail. What Sheriff Garris doesn't realize is that the town is about to get a visit from one of it's most infamous citizens, and he's not friendly.VII. Friday The 13th Part VII: The New Blood (1988): As a child, Tina Shepard (Lar Park Lincoln) unconsciously used latent psychokinetic powers to kill her father by drowning him in Crystal Lake after witnessing his abuse on her mother. Now as a young woman, her mother takes her back to the same lakeside residence so that her powers can be studied (and exploited) by a doctor. But during an attempt to raise her father from the dead, she accidentally resurrects someone else long ago left to die in the lake: Jason Voorhees (now played by Kane Hodder). Jason is back and now he's meaner than ever, but has he finally met his match in the form of the psychokinetic Tina?VIII. Friday The 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan (1989): A year after the events in The New Blood, Jason (Kane Hodder) lies dormant on the bottom of Crystal Lake. A boat with two teenagers, Jim (Todd Shaffer) and Suzi (Tiffany Paulsen) drop anchor for a romantic evening at the lake. The anchor hits a cable tow at the bottom of the lake which sparks and revives Jason. He stows aboard the boat and kills the occupants. He then pulls up the anchor and lets the boat sail with the current. The boat later comes to a harbor and Jason climbs aboard a ship called the Lazarus. The ship is boarded by a group of graduating high school seniors who are going on a trip to New York City. What they don't realize is that they are carrying an extremely dangerous stowaway.COMMENTS: Along with Freddy Krueger of the Nightmare On Elm Street series, Jason Voorhees was the other most infamous boogeyman of the 1980s. As a little kid, I was just as afraid of him as I was of Freddy. The writer of the first film, Victor Miller, was just trying to make a horror movie about a summer camp, but his creation grew into something beyond his wildest dreams. How ironic that Jason Voorhees went from being a seconds long cameo appearance in the first film to the main focus of all of the other films. Most people don't even know that Jason isn't the killer in the original film. Jason was originally meant to be a normal child, but make-up and EFX wizard Tom Savini (Dawn Of The Dead (1978)) felt that the Jason character wasn't special enough. He decided to base Jason on a drunk that he used to see around his neighborhood as a child; the man had one ear lower than the other, one eye lower than the other, etc. Savini ultimately designed Jason to be a retarded, deformed, hydrospephalic pinhead. I feel that the original film was the most classic and inventive out of all of the films, even though Mrs. Voorhees was the killer instead of Jason. Victor Miller ultimately never had any involvment with any of the sequels and he has reportedly never even seen any of the sequels as well. The second film is allright but it is nowhere near being the best. In this film it is discovered that Jason didn't actually drown in 1958, but most likely washed up on shore and lived in the woods as a reclusive hermit for the next twenty-something years. Apparently he witnessed his mother's decapitation from afar and set out to take out revenge on Alice, as well as all teenagers in general. What most people don't know about this film is that Jason Voorhees does not wear the hockey mask which became such an iconic symbol, but rather a burlap sack with one eyehole. Jason is seen without his mask in a dream sequence at the end of the film, and he looks deformed but with a full head of hair. Every other film depicts him as being completely bald, including Part 3 which takes place immediately after this film. Since this is a dream sequence, I guess it shouldn't be taken seriously but it should be noted that many of the other sequels also contradicted previous entries in the series. Part 3 is a very good film and is sometimes referred to as Friday The 13th Part 3-D, because it was made during an early '80s revival of 3-D films along with Jaws 3-D (1983) and Amityville 3-D (1983). This would explain why so many objects seem to pop out at the screen. Unfortunately the film is presented here in flat screen 2-D. I wish they would have released this film with 3-D glasses like Freddy's Dead in the Nightmare On Elm Street Collection. It just looks really ridiculous when it is not shown in the intended 3-D. When Jason is shown unmasked, his make-up looks very similar to his child-like version of the first film but now as a 40-year-old man. This is also the first film where Jason wears the infamous hockey mask, which he steals from one of his victims. After this film, Jason just basically became a copy of Michael Myers from the Halloween series. The Final Chapter is a very good entry in the series and (along with the first film) is my personal favorite. This is the only other Friday film in which Tom Savini did the make-up and effects. He designed Jason unmasked to be a 40-year-old version of his original creation. It looks very similar to the make-up in Part 3, but I feel that Jason's face in that film was much more animated. This film was really meant to be the "final" film, but the fans still demanded more. Ironically, this wouldn't be the only sequel to contain the word "final" in the title. A New Beginning must be one of the worst slasher films of all time. It is just bad-bad-bad. Fans were really dissappointed to find out that Jason wasn't even in the film. It turns out that the killer was just a guy pretending to be Jason. This was a really stupid attempt to try to bring back the franchise and whoever gave this script the green-light should be shot. The fans would never accept anybody else as Jason, so Paramount Studios decided to bring him back. Since he was dead for good, the studio decided to bring him back to life Frankenstein-style via a bolt of lightning. From this film on, Jason is a Frankenstein-like zombie and more-or-less unkillable. This was another very good entry in the series and a huge improvement over A New Beginning, which many fans discount altogether. The New Blood was another good entry in the series and many fans feel that the look of Jason in this film is the ideal look for Jason. The make-up and effects artists in this film decided to make him look like he has gone through seven films of being drowned, shot at, stabbed, burned, etc. His mask looks extremely damaged, his skin looks like rotting flesh, his clothes are basically scraps, and you can even see bones exposed through his skin, most notably his spinal cord through his back. When shown unmasked, he looks very skull-like. This film was nick-named Jason vs. Carrie, since the psychokinetic teen Tina Shepherd has many similarities to the title character from Carrie (1976). Jason Takes Manhattan is ultimately a let-down in the series and many fans feel that the film was falsely advertised. Most of the movie takes place on a ship, as opposed to Manhattan. The filmmakers were really trying to make a Freddy vs. Jason film, but it didn't pull through and unfortunately they decided to go with this horrible script. One thing I really hated was Jason's ability to move from one location to a distant other in only a few seconds span of time. The film also depicted Jason as being a normal child originally, who deteriorated from being underwater for so many years. This film is loaded with contradictions to previous entries. Interest in the franchise was already going down, but Jason Takes Manhattan was ultimately the final nail in the coffin and the franchise was later sold off to New Line Cinema (who also owned the Nightmare On Elm Street and Texas Chainsaw Massacre franchises.) The only films on this DVD box-set are the ones which were produced by Paramount. The other sequels which followed were Jason Goes To The Hell: The Final Friday (1993) [ironically it also wasn't the final film], Jason X (2002), and Freddy vs. Jason (2003), which teamed up Jason with Freddy Krueger of the Nightmare On Elm Street Series franchise. This film ultimately became the most successful film of either franchise. At the moment, there are plans to make a follow-up to Freddy vs. Jason and even adding another horror franchise boogeyman to the fold such as Pinhead (Hellraiser franchise) or Michael Myers (Halloween franchise). Whether this film gets made or not, production is already underway for a remake/reboot of the original film. The film will supposedly have Jason as the killer, as opposed to Mrs. Voorhees, and he will be wearing the hockey mask. Friday The 13th has ultimately become one of the most successful and long-lasting horror franchises of all time. Many of the films also featured many well-known stars in some of their first roles, such as Kevin Bacon (Tremors (1990)) in the first film, Crispin Glover (Back To The Future (1985)) in The Final Chapter, and Corey Feldman (The Goonies (1985)) in The Final Chapter and A New Beginning. Overall I would recommend this film to any die-hard slasher film addict. All of the films are presented in the original widescreen format (though I still wish that Part 3 was released with 3-D glasses.) Some, but not all, of the films are presented with a feature commentary. The box set also comes with a seperate disc entitled Killer Extras which is loaded with trailers, interviews, and several other goodies.
