reviewText: REGION 4 BUYERS BEWAREFirst off, I want any one in region 4 land to know that the Australian release of this box set is bogus. And I give it no stars for this reason...Finally the box set was released for region 4 (Australia). I first looked at the box and wondered why it didn't show any information on it about what was on the discs. I bought it anyway and was seriously p***** off to find out that they are the exact it discs that where released individually with no extras and there is no bonus disc.  There are no bonus features, except what was already on them, like trailers, which are NOT a bonus to me. (Part 1 does have features, but their nothing new to the already released single edition, because they are exactly the same as the individual editions sold separately for months before hand.  So I was completely p**** off because I already had them all. I wanted the new bonus stuff like on the region 1 discs. How dare they release a box set with the same name and same cover as the region 1 box set that is NOT the same?After my bad purchase of the R4 version of the box set. I purchased the region 1 version and am so much happier with it.Region 1 box set: 4 stars * * * *Region 4 box set: minus 5 stars - - - -______________________Friday The 13th[* * * *] 4 starsThis is where it all began. Years ago a little boy drowned in camp Crystal Lake because the camp councillors where busy watching each other rather then the little deformed boy who couldn't swim. 2 murders took place and the camp closed down for many years. Everyone believed that boy drowned or some say he's still alive & some say his ghost haunts the lake but one thing for sure; something's happening to the new group of councillors looking to re-build and re-open the campsite.The original movie is what some call the best. But for me, it's just one of the favourites of the never-ending series but not my favourite. Its special FX had never been seen before at the time it was released. But looking at it these days, you may have seen them before and seen them done better, but keep in mind they hadn't been done before until this movie, and there where no computers backing those days. An impressive make-up FX done in this is Kevin Bacon's death scene. It was originally cut from the theatrical releases in America for being to gruesome for the FAA approval for an R-rating. I'm not sure if it was put back into this DVD release or just included as a deleted scene. But it IS in the region 4 release of the movie, along with featurettes and things. I would highly recommend you purchase the region 4 release of this episode (part 1) but please look into region codes and settings before you do so.______________________Part 2[* * *]Continuing off from a short period after the end of what happened in part 1. Alice thinks it's all over, until it's discovered that Jason is still alive, and he gets his revenge for his momma's death. He then returns to Camp Crystal Lake. A few years pass by and a camp is opened next-door to where "camp-blood" is. The guy who owns it tells the councillors not to cross over into that campsite because of all the strange things have happened there. But they won't listen, and when you snoop around Jason's territory, you're going to be prosecuted the only way Jason knows how.______________________Part 3[* * *]They thought he was dead, but he won't stay down. The story hasn't changed that much, horny councillors at the lake, sex, drugs & blood. But this instalment is where Jason first puts on the trademark hockey mask. For those who say sequels are never better then the original, I guess they forget that when they think of Friday The 13th, they think of Jason Voorhees in a hockey mask. And it wasn't until this instalment that he first dawned it.Also, some scenes in this will seem stupid to the home audience because originally this movie was in 3D. So expect a lot of scenes set up for a3D effect that might've been cool in the cinema when it came out, but without it being in 3D on the DVD, it looks pretty lame.______________________Part 4: The Final Chapter.[* * *]The final chapter isn't the end of the series. But it is the last of one long movie. If you played parts 1 to 4 back to back, they all kick off where the last one ended. This time around Jason still isn't dead. And the residents of the area are told to be on the lookout for an escaped maniac. Tommy Jarvis (Corey Feldmen) is a boy who loves his video games and scary masks, he's quite the artist but he finds himself having to face off against Jason.______________________(5) A New Beginning[* * *]Tommy Jarvis may have survived, but it's left him mentally unstable. He is put into a mental hospital and later transferred to the nuthouse in Crystal Lake to help his rehabilitation. But he isn't sure if he just sees Jason in his imagination or if he really is there.A lot of people hated this one; I did to the first time I saw it, but when I watched it again, it's really not so bad. I think the movie gets more bad press then it really deserved.______________________(6) Jason Lives[ * * * * * ]This is my favourite of the series. Tommy Jarvis still isn't convinced Jason is dead. So he returns to Crystal Lake and him and the Kotter kid dig up Jason's grave on a dark and stormy night. Tommy has a psychotic episode when he reaches Jason's grave and stabs him with a metal pole. That pole ends up being a lightning conductor and Jason is back from the dead, bigger, stronger, and badder then ever. Now a walking zombie that cant be killed, Tommy is up S### creek with Jason after him.The end is one of those "where did you get your information from" thing, but its only a movie. Alice Cooper provides a couple of great songs for the film; it's just a shame the video clip for "man behind the mask" was not included L______________________(7) The New Blood[ * * ]Years ago a little girl living on the lake said, "I wish you where dead" to her daddy. And her daddy ended up being sucked into Crystal Lake. She blamed herself for his death and it's really messed her up. Years later her therapist has brought her back to Crystal Lake with her mother to help her. Only he's not really trying to help, he's brought her to make her angry so that she can channel her ESP and Telekineses so he can study it. She tries to use her powers to bring her father back from the dead, but instead, wonder woman resurrects Jason.______________________(8) Jason Takes Manhattan[*]Jason takes Manhattan? You would think that the title might mean that Jason takes over New York, wouldn't you? Well he doesn't. The title should be "Jason goes to Manhattan, eventually" Most of the movie takes place on a ship heading to New York City. Why Jason got on the boat is anybody's guess? But Jason does not take anything. He does little when he is in New York for his brief moment. Then he is killed off in the stupidest way possible in the end.This is the weakest Jason movie. It stank and the rights to Friday The 13th movies soon enough got handed over to New Line Cinema who didn't do a much better job then the last 2.______________________New Line Cinema owns the copyright to part 9: Jason Goes To Hell [* * *], 10: Jason X [* *] and Freddy VS Jason [* * * *] so don't complain that they were not included in this box set.Bonus Disc contains a lot of deleted scenes, interviews, pics and random stuff for the Jason fan to enjoy. The only downfalls to this box set is that part one is not the same better edition released on region 4, and part 7 wasn't shown in it's entirety like so many people claim make that stinking movie a lot better.For those wondering if these are flip discs or not. They are not. They are single sides. part 1 and 2 on one disc, and so on.

reviewText: So Region 1 DVD friday fans are really being ripped off here. There is already an Australian and British disc of "Friday the 13th" available with a special made documentary on the production of the movie with interviews with Sean Cunningham, Adrienne King, Harry Crosby and Manfredini and others. You can order it TODAY!To make matters even worse for Region 1 fans - THERE IS A COMMENTARY TRACK FROM SEAN S. CUNNINGHAM INCLUDED ON THIS RELEASE which is NOT included in this box set release? WHY NOT? It already exists.I have a copy of this disc (purchased when I was recently in Australia). I suggest you look into possible ways in which you can aquire this disc. Unlike the US where the discs are released through Paramount, the Australian distributor is Warner Home Video (I think - have to check).For serious Friday fans this Region 4 or 2 purchase is essential. The following info is taken from amazon.co.uk"Friday the 13th may be the least worthy of all horror "classics", but it's still nice to have an edition that (unlike earlier video releases) offers a 16x9-enhanced 1.85:1 restored image and a healthy dose of extras. The making of the movie is covered by a 20-minute "Return to Crystal Lake" featurette and a commentary track with input from many of the creatives (Cunningham, composer Harry Manfredini, stars Adrienne King and Betsy Palmer, writer Victor Miller). Some anecdotes get repeated, but there's a lot of solid background material."(...)Don't get ripped off - by all means by the Paramount box set if you're a die-hard fan, but you cannot afford to be without the commentary from Cunningham. Why did they shaft us Region 1'ers. Without the US support Jason would never have become the titan he is today.NB. You'll need a DVD player and television capable of displayed PAL video to watch these features. I was really surprised to see that these important extras were to be excluded from the box set.You can thank me once you've ordered this DVD and completed your FRIDAY collection.AND WHY NO 3-D on PART III? That was the best thing about that film. PARAMOUNT - you suck and you're really shafting the fans of this series. Is it because you hold us in contempt or you just DON'T CARE?Fu-fu-fu-yu-yu-yu

reviewText: There are plenty of devoted hardcore Friday the 13th fans out there, just about all of whom have been sick and tired of Paramount's feature-less DVD releases of each film in the series.  And now, finally, Paramount has released the first eight films featuring everyone's favorite hockey masked killer in a DVD set which promises the extras we've all been waiting for.  And yes, a disc with deleted footage, interviews, and such is included, and a few of the films have commentaries, but the decision of whether or not to buy this is left soley up to the fan.  For starters, the films are NOT uncut (even though some uncut footage can be found in the supplemental features) which is a big downside, and while four of the films have commentaries, you'd figure that the first film would have a commentary by director/producer Sean S. Cunningham or gore master Tom Savini, but there is none to be found.  As for the films themselves, part 4 is the best of the series, with the first installment and Jason Lives behind it.  After that, it's basically the kind of formulaic slasher fodder that was so apparent in the 80's and beyond.  All in all, hardcore Friday the 13th fans will no doubt snatch this up just to nitpick it, but for others we can hope that someday the uncut versions will be one day made available (especially considering the DVD "double dipping" of late, it could be inevitable).

reviewText: Fans of the Friday films have been screaming for years for uncut versions of the famed slashers.  It's been the number one request.  So finally, Paramount puts out a box set.It pretty much sums up Paramount's opinion of these films.  They don't think much of them.  These low budget flicks made the studio a lot of money, though after a few the profits began to shrink until they decided to just sink the series with Part VIII.  Then they sold the whole thing off to New Line, which recently proved the formula could make a decent bundle of cash (see Freddy vs Jason).For years all we had were the bare-bones DVDs of the Friday flicks, and they weren't always cheap.  Now the studio thoughtfully puts two movies per disc, making you wonder about the care for quality, for one.  Sure, it's probably nit-picking.  The Friday films are not known for amazing cinematography, or sound, or anything spectacular, but they are very popular.  And companies like Anchor Bay continue to do bang-up jobs on even the most obscure horror flicks, reverently restoring them and including tons of extras for the horror fanatic.  So here we do get some commentaries, which is nice.  And there are deleted scenes.  But it's not the uncut versions.  Paramount blanketly claims they 'lost' that footage.  Given their contempt for the series (and most likely for the fans), who knows?  Maybe they did, maybe they didn't, though I have a hard time believing that they lost the footage for all eight films!  And what of John Buechler's attempts to get an uncut The New Blood released?  More 'lost' footage?  Instead, Paramount slap this together and judging from reviews here, the fans are not happy.So what do I do now?  I own most of these already.  I might think about actually buying this outright if I can find it real cheap, or used.  I like the Friday films for what they are, and it's partly nostalgia.  They're hardly scary, they're very cynical, and some of them are just downright abominable (see Part VIII, and even Part 3 is pretty damn bad--and they can't even bother putting it out in 3D!)  Look at what Anchor Bay just did for Dawn of the Dead.  On the other hand, I think Paramount likes the money these movies continue to make, but they still can't really be bothered with them much.  Who knows?  Maybe it is too much work to 'restore' these movies, but every time I see another 'forgotten' Italian 'masterpiece' of the genre released on DVD with all of this special attention, I think Paramount still holds these movies and this franchise in contempt, regardless of how much cash they made.  It's kind of typical.  No doubt there were more 'reputable' clinkers that would have hurt the studio's books had it not been for cheap and ready-made Friday movies to make up the money.New Line put out great DVDs for Jason X and Freddy vs Jason, indicating that they at least value the formula a little bit more than the profiteers who helmed this series for Paramount during the 80s.

reviewText: The thing I've always liked about the "Friday the 13th" movies is the purity of their intent.  There's no symbolism, no comment on society, no hidden messages, and no complex backstories.  The entire purpose of each movie in the series is to supply the killer with an ample amount of victims to be dispatched in a bloody fashion, with a bit of gratuitous nudity thrown in (probably to please the largly male audience of these movies).  All that was asked in return by Paramount pictures was profit for the movie studio.  And, throughout most of the 1980's, Paramount made tons of money off these pictures, which they never put much money into.  As most "Friday" fans know, Paramount was always rather embarrassed to be associated with this franchise, which was hated by critics and all sorts of parents and religious groups, and once profits started decreasing, Paramount let Jason move to another studio and that was that.Anyway, the initial round of DVDs were ok, but lacked any sort of features (commentaries, deleted scenes, documentaries, uncut versions) that have made the DVD format so great.  Many "Friday" fans felt that this was a slap in the face by Paramount, not only to a franchise that brought so much financial reward to the studio, but also the film series' dedicated following.  So, along comes this box set to rectify the situation.  Unfortunately, Paramount has decided to only go halfway.  So, let's go through what this box has to offer:-All 8 movies on 4 discs.  I don't think I need to review each movie here.  The good part about this is that if you are a new "Friday" fan, or one who never had the DVDs before, its much cheaper to buy this box than purchase each one individually.  Unfortunately, none of these movies are presented in their uncut versions.  Also, most of the original cover art from the original VHS versions has been replaced with new art that is much lamer than the originals.-There are commentaries on SOME of the movies, specifically parts 3, 6, 7, & 8.  I don't really get why the studio only went part of the way on this, unless some people involved in the other movies simply refuse to do commentary.  I was particularly surpised that part 1 had no commentary.  Now, I'm not one of those fans who has been waiting for the Kevin Bacon commentary to the original film (its never gonna happen), but I thought that at least Sean Cunningham would do one.  The part 3 commentary, which features 4 of the cast members, is probably the best (I find that group commentaries tend to offer better and more entertaining comments than do commentaries by an individual).  Parts 6 & 8 only feature the writer/director of each film, and part 7 features John Carl Bechler (who spends much of the time complaining about cuts to the movie) and Kane Hodder.-The 5th disc features a number of documentaries.  There is one special for each film.  While, in some ways, they were very interesting, in other ways I was struck as to how cheaply this was done.  While the documentary for the 1st film features a number of key cast and crew members (Sean Cunningham, Adrienne King, Betsy Palmer, Tom Savini, and Ari Lehman), the others tend to feature only one or two people who worked on the film.  Part 5 gets the biggest shaft, and only features Corey Feldman, who was only in the movie for a few minutes, and who spends most of the time trying to pitch his idea for what he calls "Friday H20", which would be to ignore all the movies after part 5, and bring Corey back as Tommy Jarvis for one final battle with Jason.  Fans might be impressed by Corey's dedication to the character and the films (which he does really seem to enjoy), but I can't help thinking that Corey Feldman would push the idea of himself reprising any popular role he had in an attempt to regain the popularity he had as a teen.  Aside from the specials for each movie, there are documentaries on the special effects for parts 1, 4, & 7, a special on "Friday the 13th" collectibles, and a short collection of deleted and extended scenes.All this seems like a meal that leaves you half full or like settling for the girl (or guy) you know isn't right for you because you'd rather not be single.  You get some satisfaction out of it, but it could have been so much better.  I ask myself, "Why can't Paramount just liscense out these movies to a company that will treat them much better?", then I realize that, like myself, many other "Friday" fans will be buying this, knowing full well that they aren't going to get all that they want, but feeling something is better than nothing.  This box will sell, and that's all that matters to the studio.

reviewText: Paramount truly are quite shameful, lazy, and contemptable. Everything about this 'Ultimate' release screams "cheap-a$$" quite loudly. And here's why.I think it is forgiveable that Paramount didn't see fit to release these movies in their uncut forms. It would lose them money in some circles if this boxset were to not be stocked in Blockbuster. So for this release, uncut death scenes have been prepared.Here are the catches, and they are quite significant: 1) gore footage for the original Friday the 13th and Part 6 are presented in horizontal SPLIT SCREENS alongside the R-rated versions. That's right, Jason fans- it's squeezed into only HALF the screen space. That's 2 out of 3 movies. 2) The gore footage from Part 7 looks quite bad, in a very rough made-for-video way in which the age shows a lot of wear and tear. There's bonus footage here as well from Part 4, but it's made-for-tv deleted scenes that don't include any gore.Also, remember when Paramount put out the first Friday on DVD? You could finally see Annie's throat-slitting in it's entirety. Well, Paramount's decided to cut that back out. So that means if you ever want to see it again, you have to buy the original on DVD separately. Which I'll be doing, you can bet.Here are some other things you might like to know. The set contains 4 discs of movies. Each disc has 2 movies on each disc side. I'm sorry, but my DVD players freeze erratically whenever a disc has more than 3 hours and 10 minutes of stuff on them. 20th Century Fox released The Family Guy TV seasons in these very slim single cases- why didn't Paramount have this brainstorm too?! That way, we could get 1 movie a disc, like we deserve. At least that would show Paramount thought about someone else.The 1 Bonus Disc contains a few truly bogus featurettes. Paramount didn't even get half the cast members that would have been willing to do interviews and commentaries. They just had some people go off to a convention 1 year and get a mere handful of people there on camera. They neglected to put effort into contacting actresses Kimberly Beck and Melanie Kinnamon, who have been very outspoken about their enthusiasm onset and their appreciation for the series fans. Also, director Steve Miner is absent from participation on the featurettes or commentaries. Yet he's been on bonus features for the House, Halloween H20, and Last House on the Left DVDs. So sorry, I don't buy that he didn't want to participate here.The only real work Paramount did here was on the commentaries. The commentaries for only 4 movies. The directors of Friday the 13th's 6, 7, and 8 do commentaries. Jason actor Kane Hodder joins the director on Part 7, and the cast of Part 3 do a commentary. But there's yet another catch! These commentaries - at least the one I heard for Part 3, have the worst sound quality I've heard from a big studio commentary since John Waters track for the Cecil B Demented DVD. And even that was less TIN-can sounding than this.This boxset is the biggest insult to fans of this series. And even at $57, this is overpriced. I urge everyone here to pay attention to the rumors I'm hearing about future re-re-releasing of these movies on yet another boxset or individual uncut releases. reviewText: Within this box set lays some of the most popular horror films ever made featuring one of the most popular villains in the history of cinema, Jason Voorhees. Legend has it that Jason Voorhees drowned in the lake at Camp Crystal Lake in 1957. Since then his mother took her revenge on the area, slaughtering everyone involved with the place up until that fateful night at "Camp Blood" when she was decapitated out of self defense. After that, Jason Voorhees raises from his watery grave (at full adult size) to seek revenge on anyone who dare enter Camp Crystal Lake and the surrounding area.Really, the first seven Friday the 13th films tell a wonderful horror story of a legend that comes to life. Jason Voorhees is like Big Foot or Loch Ness. He is a creature that people believe in, however, scientifically should not exist, but does exist and is in your face!The movies all look and sound great. My only problem with the picture or sound quality in the set is with Part 4. They did not improve it from the original single disc release and it still contains the same audio problems and ultra grainy (at times) picture. Again, these problems are brief and do not ruin the over all experience of the film, but they can be an annoyance.As far as extra features go, we get a nice disc full of documentaries with cast and crew interviews. We get commentary tracks for only half the series. I don't know why they could not provide commentary for all of the movies though.Most people's biggest complaint is the lack of unrated uncut versions of the films. I can see why people would have a problem there, but you've got to understand when these movies were made. In the 1980s, there were no such things as DVDs and Paramount claims that they do not have the uncut footage. They said it was just thrown away back then. The footage they have now, do to fans and directors coming forward would be (to Paramount) too expensive to re-master, which is sad. We do get uncut footage in the bonus disc which is cool, but some of us wish they would just put it back into the movies. What I did like was how they gave us more of Mrs. Voorhees' death in the box set version of the original then they did in the single disc edition of it. That was nice of them.All in all, despite some of the above mentioned flaws, this is a very good box set. For fans of the horror movie genre and/or of the Friday the 13th movies in particular should have a great time with this box set. Heck, it contains the best movies in the series by far (the first seven). You also get Part 8, which is when the series started really going down hill.

reviewText: Fans have been begging Paramount for years to release the unrated and uncut Friday the 13th films.  The "Blockbuster and Wal-Mart won't sell them" excuse I've heard, here and there, is patently untrue.  Both Blockbuster and Wal-Mart sell and rent unrated films (call either of them up and ask if they carry the unrated edition of "Bad Santa," if you need proof).  They simply don't sell or rent NC-17 movies.So what's Paramount's excuse?  No input from the Directors of the films?  Nope, that's not it.  John Carl Buechler, director of Friday the 13th Part VII has openly campaigned for an unrated version to be released (so fans can finally see "the new BLOOD").  Tom McLoughlin, director of Friday the 13th Part VI, told me directly that he has contacted Paramount, letting them know that he would be willing to do a director's commentary AND re-edit an unrated Director's Cut of Jason Lives.  The studio didn't take him up on his offer to create an unrated Director's cut (he does provide commentary on part VI).  If this box set is any indication, they never will.  Kane Hodder, Jason in Paramount's F13 6, 7 and 8 has been screaming for unrated and uncut versions, and has expressed a desire to do commentary for each of the films (including the ones he didn't star in).  So why, at the very least, isn't there commentary on EVERY disc?  I suspect it's because Paramount wanted to cram two movies onto each disc, leaving no space for commentary or other valuable extras on some of the films (and giving a compressed picture, that isn't much better than what you get on video).Why aren't the films uncut and unrated? Because Paramount is too stubborn to release them that way.  It has been known for years that Paramount has been "ashamed" of this series.  They don't get what it is that makes the movies great, and therefore think they can give fans bargain bin box sets like this, rather than presenting them with the quality box set the Friday the 13th films DESERVE.This should have been a 16 disc set.  Each film should have had 2 discs, one featuring the unrated version, the other the theatrical version.  There should have been commentary on the unrated version (disc 1) for the movie, and extras on the rated version (disc 2).  It's a shame that Paramount won't sell the entire series to New Line, a studio who has expressed interest in doing a comprehensive box set, which would include the long sought after uncut films.If New Line's Freddy vs. Jason wouldn't have been the hit it was, fans wouldn't even be getting this box set.  Then again, they wouldn't have been missing much.  Fans should let Paramount know what they think, by voting with their dollars. reviewText: Most of the reviews about this set have been focused on the fact that they did not include the director/un-rated cuts of these films. There have also been folks that have stated the sound is not re-mastered and is presented in Mono. All of the above is true but one of the films, part 7, is in Dolby 5.1. Part 8 is in Ultra-Sound along with Part 6. All the other movies are presented with the mono audio track only. However, my biggest gripe with this set is the fact that the video has not been re-mastered. Others have stated that the video was re-mastered and if it was, which I seriously doubt, it was the worst re-mastering job I have ever seen. The copies have a ton of scratches and dust on the negatives, which you can see throughout all the movies. The blacks are not deep and the color saturation is poor, which leads to color bleeds, and scenes where you cannot view characters very well in the dark. I can deal with the mono audio, not having the uncut versions, but the video quality is VHS at best just like the original versions of these movies they released on DVD. Paramount once again is making a ton of money on these movies without spending hardly anything at all. I would love to see the profit margins on these movies since the time they were release till now. I can guarantee you that these movies are probably in the top ten biggest profit makers for Paramount as compared to the cost invested in them for making the movie, VHS tapes, and DVDs.FOLLOW-UP to review:Mr. Scott A. Minge states that the original audio was in mono and the grainy video is due to the original. Well, I am 39 and I saw the original in a theater not on home video. Now back to Paramount's awful video restoration, it can be cleaned up by digitally restoring the film frame by frame. My God they did this for movies from the 30s, 40s, and 50s. Those movies look far superior to Friday the 13th. The bottom line as I stated in my original review is that Paramount did not want to spend the money on this type of restoration. Let me give you some examples of movies that are as old, if not older, that have been restored properly: Evil Dead Special Edition 1980 (even a lower budget movie filmed on 16MM), Dawn of the Dead Special Edition 1978 (ultra low budget again and again filmed in 16MM), and finally Halloween 1978 (again another low budget film). By the way Halloween started the slasher genre not Friday the 13th. I own all the movies above plus the Friday the 13th set. It amazes me that someone would defend sub-par video quality when there are many examples of prints in far worse condition that have been restored to ten times what the Friday the 13th video quality is. It is also absurd to think that the directors/writers of these films wanted them presented in grainy/dusty restoration for DVD. Did they intentionally scratch all the negatives and add dust to them when they were shown in the theaters? Not a chance, unfortunately these movies looked at their best during their theatrical run which is a shame because all the movies I mentioned above look better on DVD than they did in the theaters.As for the director cuts they do exist and if Mr. Minge owned the set he would see exactly what was cut from the movies. Unfortunately many of the negatives are supposedly lost according to Paramount so we will never get to see the directors true vision of these films. However, the last disk of the set does contain scenes that were removed to avoid an X rating which means they could have been edited back into the movie. But once again this would cost Paramount more money and decrease their very high profit margins which is of the utmost importance to them.One final note, I own over 500 DVDs and I can say without a shadow of doubt that this series is in the top 10 of worst video restorations that I own.

reviewText: I've already wote reviews for the individual films, so I'm not gonna bother with all that crap, so I'm writing about the set features. The extras disk consists of an 8 part documentary that you can watch in pieces or in one lump sum that runs about 1hr and 40 minutes total. Jason's Victims Tell All is decent, though it could have just as well been part of the original 8 part documentary.  The Memorabilia section is only 10 minutes or so if I remember correctly.  Kinda pointless, yet harmless too.  Tales From The Cutting Room Floor is what I think drove alot of people to purchase this set, and you might be a bit disappointed if that's true.  Yes, it is neat to see various cut scenes(especially those from part 7 which probably suffered the most censorship of any FT13TH film), but I have two complaints about this.  First, where were the deleted scenes from part 8?  There were a few scenes cut from that film.  Part 2 as well.  And like everyone else states, why weren't these scenes put back into the films for this set?  I mean, c'mon.  Ask any fan, that's what they've wanted for quite some time now.  I know Paramount is embarassed by these films, but they made quite a bit of money from them, so why not give fans the benefit of the doubt if you're going to put out an Ultimate Edition.  It would be more than worth the extra money to put these scenes back in(and it can't cost THAT much to do it).  And of course, trailers.  The Friday trailers are pretty fun.  All in all I'm pleased with this set.  I like the fact that it's all the "Friday" films from Paramount and not the rotten "Jason" films that New Line has been doing. reviewText: Slasher films are the easiest movies to write.  They practically write themselves, as basically you introduce 10-12 people and over the next hour and a half cut them apart.  The rest is filler, like in this series, dealing with yo-yos, nerd-dancers, and foul-mouthed hillbillies.  The crowd doesn't care as long as you're inventive with your murders, which isn't too difficult.  But even the soap-operatic elements of the story are compelling: young boy drowns, returns years later to wreak havoc on teenagers after one kills his mother.  It's lead to 10 films and a lot of movie folklore that fans have eaten up.  So if you're a new writer and you like horror, you're going to have a pretty easy go of it.  Villian.  Victims.  Ending.  Couldn't be simpler.So if you're new to writing watch this film again if you don't know it by heart already:).
